{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox comics creator | name = Sempé | image = Salon du livre de Paris 2011 - Jean-Jacques Sempé - 005.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Jean-Jacques Sempé (2011) | birth_name = Jean-Jacques Sempé | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1932|08|17}} | birth_place = [[Bordeaux]], France | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = French | area = Cartoonist | alias = | notable works = ''Le petit Nicolas'' | awards = }} '''Jean-Jacques Sempé''', usually known as '''Sempé''' ({{IPA-fr|sɑ̃pe|lang}}; born 17 August 1932), is a French [[cartoonist]]. He is known for the series of children's books he created with [[René Goscinny]], ''[[Le petit Nicolas]]'', and also for his poster-like illustrations, usually drawn from a distant or high viewpoint depicting detailed countrysides or cities.<ref name="indep">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/jean-jacques-sempeacute-luck-of-the-draw-5330966.html|title= Jean-Jacques Sempé: Luck of the draw|date= 21 October 2006|work=The Independent |location=UK |accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life=== Sempé was from school as a young man, and then failed to pass exams for the post office, a bank and the railroad.<ref name="mcgrath">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/08/books/08semp.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss |title= Jean-Jacques Sempé’s Tales of Two Cities|author=Charles McGrath|date= 8 November 2006 |work=New York Times|accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref> He then found work selling tooth powder as a door-to-door salesman<ref name="mcgrath"/> and also worked delivering wine by bicycle in the [[Gironde]].<ref name="guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2001/nov/24/art|title= Drawing on life's little ironies: Cartoonist Jean-Jacques Sempé tells Laura Moser why he is a loss to football|date= 24 November 2001|author=Laura Moser|work=The Guardian|accessdate=11 May 2009}}</ref> After lying about his age, he joined the [[French army|army]] in 1950, since it was “the only place that would give me a job and a bed,” he subsequently explained, and would occasionally get into trouble for drawing while he was supposed to be keeping watch during guard duty.<ref name="mcgrath"/>
After being discharged from the army, he moved to Paris and began working with [[René Goscinny]].<ref name="mcgrath"/> Sempé has spent most of his life in Paris' [[Saint-Germain-des-Prés]] district.<ref name="guardian"/>
===Artistic career=== [[File:Jean-Jacques Sempé in 2016 by Olivier Meyer.jpg|thumb|Jean-Jacques Sempé in 2016 by [[Olivier Meyer]]]] His career started in France within the context of the [[Franco-Belgian comics]] industry. His "mute" watercolors or single image sketches, where the characters speak in pictures or not at all (but somehow manage to convey a rich story) slowly gained international attention. He won his first award in 1952 which is given to encourage young amateur artists to turn professional.
His work has appeared as the cover of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' magazine many times. Sempé’s full page cartoons appeared in ''[[Paris Match]]'' for many years.<ref name="indep"/> In the 1950s, Sempé became renowned for his creation of a character named Nicolas in his cartoons for ''Le Moustique'', a comic book proposed by René Goscinny to Sempé.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lambiek.net/artists/s/sempe_jj.htm|title= Jean-Jacques Sempé|publisher=Lambiek.net|accessdate=10 May 2009}}</ref> ''[[Le petit Nicolas|Le Petit Nicolas]]'' appeared from 1954 in Le Moustique and Sempé drew upon childhood influences and memories to illustrate the comic. In 1960, the comic ''Le Petit Nicolas'' was published in ''[[Pilote]]'' magazine. It was unusual at the time modern children's literature given that it is centered around the experience of the child, rather than an adult interpretation of the world.
In general though, Sempé rarely draws from life, and draws something every day, putting sketches aside when he gets bored with them.<ref name="indep"/>
